rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.)
rev.diff:
Line 35: Line 35:
''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' depicts Picard's command of the [[USS Enterprise (NCC-1701-D)|USS ''Enterprise'' (NCC-1701-D)]].<ref name="tngcompanion">{{cite book|title=Star Trek: The Next Generation Companion|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2003|author=Nemeck, Larry|id=ISBN 0-7434-5798-6}}</ref> The [[Encounter at Farpoint|pilot episode]] shows the ship's mission to investigate a problem at Farpoint Station, which becomes sidetracked when [[Q (Star Trek)|Q]] makes Picard "representative" in a trial charging humanity with being a "dangerously savage child-race".<ref name="tngcompanion" /> Picard persuades Q to test humanity, and Q chooses as the test's first stage the crew's performance at Farpoint.<ref name="tngcompanion" /> The trial "ends" seven years later (when Q reminds Picard that it never does), in the [[All Good Things...|series finale]], when humanity is absolved by Picard's demonstration that the species has the capacity to explore the "possibilities of existence".<ref name="tngcompanion" />
''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' depicts Picard's command of the [[USS Enterprise (NCC-1701-D)|USS ''Enterprise'' (NCC-1701-D)]].<ref name="tngcompanion">{{cite book|title=Star Trek: The Next Generation Companion|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2003|author=Nemeck, Larry|id=ISBN 0-7434-5798-6}}</ref> The [[Encounter at Farpoint|pilot episode]] shows the ship's mission to investigate a problem at Farpoint Station, which becomes sidetracked when [[Q (Star Trek)|Q]] makes Picard "representative" in a trial charging humanity with being a "dangerously savage child-race".<ref name="tngcompanion" /> Picard persuades Q to test humanity, and Q chooses as the test's first stage the crew's performance at Farpoint.<ref name="tngcompanion" /> The trial "ends" seven years later (when Q reminds Picard that it never does), in the [[All Good Things...|series finale]], when humanity is absolved by Picard's demonstration that the species has the capacity to explore the "possibilities of existence".<ref name="tngcompanion" />
â
[[Image:Picard as Locutus.jpg|thumb|right|Picard as Locutus of Borg]]
 
The third season finale, "[[The Best of Both Worlds (Star Trek: The Next Generation)|The Best of Both Worlds, Part I]]", depicts Picard being assimilated by the [[Borg (Star Trek)|Borg]] to serve as a bridge between humanity and the Borg; Picard is renamed "Locutus of Borg" in the process. Picard's assimilation and recovery are a critical point in the character's development, and provided [[backstory]] for the film ''[[Star Trek: First Contact]]'' and the development of [[Benjamin Sisko]], the [[protagonist]] of ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]''.<ref name="tngcompanion" /><ref>{{cite book|title=Star Trek: Deep Space Nine Companion|isbn=1-0671-5010-62|first=Terry J.|last=Erdmann |coauthors=Paula M. Block|publisher=[[Pocket Books]]|year=2000}}</ref> Stewart asked Roddenberry to keep Picard a Borg for a few more episodes beyond the third season finale, as he thought that would be more interesting than simply restoring Picard in Part II.<ref name="Hatfield" /> It is later revealed in ''First Contact'' that parts of Borg machinery are still inside Picard, and that he retains traumatic memories of assimilation.
The third season finale, "[[The Best of Both Worlds (Star Trek: The Next Generation)|The Best of Both Worlds, Part I]]", depicts Picard being assimilated by the [[Borg (Star Trek)|Borg]] to serve as a bridge between humanity and the Borg; Picard is renamed "Locutus of Borg" in the process. Picard's assimilation and recovery are a critical point in the character's development, and provided [[backstory]] for the film ''[[Star Trek: First Contact]]'' and the development of [[Benjamin Sisko]], the [[protagonist]] of ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]''.<ref name="tngcompanion" /><ref>{{cite book|title=Star Trek: Deep Space Nine Companion|isbn=1-0671-5010-62|first=Terry J.|last=Erdmann |coauthors=Paula M. Block|publisher=[[Pocket Books]]|year=2000}}</ref> Stewart asked Roddenberry to keep Picard a Borg for a few more episodes beyond the third season finale, as he thought that would be more interesting than simply restoring Picard in Part II.<ref name="Hatfield" /> It is later revealed in ''First Contact'' that parts of Borg machinery are still inside Picard, and that he retains traumatic memories of assimilation.
